title-group.article-title: Vanishing notch sensitivity approach to fatigue life prediction of notched cross-ply CFRP laminates at room temperature

article-meta.aff: Department of Engineering Mechanics and Energy, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan

author-notes.corresp: M Kawai, Department of Engineering Mechanics and Energy, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba 305-8573, Japan Email: mkawai@kz.tsukuba.ac.jp

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The effect of notch on the constant amplitude fatigue behavior of cross-ply carbon fiber-reinforced polymer (CFRP) laminates with different stacking configurations is examined. An analytical procedure that allows the prediction of the S–N relationships for notched cross-ply CFRP laminates for any notch size is also developed. Fatigue tests are first performed at room temperature on unnotched and center circular notched specimens of three kinds of non-woven cross-ply laminates, A:[90/0]3S, B:[903/03]S, and C:[03/903]S, respectively. The results from these tests show that the notched fatigue strengths of the cross-ply laminates, regardless of stacking configuration, become lower than the unnotched fatigue strengths in the range of short life according to a reduction in static strength due to notch, but the effect of notch on fatigue strength turns insignificant in the range of long life. A new engineering method for predicting the notched fatigue strengths of composites is then developed assuming that notch sensitivity vanishes during fatigue loading. The proposed fatigue model for notched composite laminates is formulated using a fatigue life prediction model for unnotched specimens and a residual strength prediction model for notched specimens. It is demonstrated that the S–N relationships for notched specimens of the three kinds of cross-ply CFRP laminates can successfully be predicted using the proposed vanishing notch sensitivity model for fatigue, regardless of notch size and stacking configuration.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Structural components in engineering applications often contain notches or holes. The stress concentration caused by notches or holes in a composite reduces its overall strength. Progressive local failure often occurs in machines and structures at the root or in the vicinity of the notches or holes involved. The fatigue behavior of fiber-reinforced polymer matrix composites, referred to them simply as composites hereafter, is thus affected by the reduction in strength due to notches or holes as well as by the deterioration of strength during cyclic loading. These observations reveal that for fatigue analysis of composites we need not only to identify the apparent S–N curves for notched composites that are different from the material S–N curves for unnotched composites, but also to develop a fatigue model that allows prediction of the S–N curves for notched composites.1 The above observations suggest that in the development of a fatigue model to predict the S–N relationship for notched composites, two kinds of capabilities should be taken into account; one is to predict the initial notched strengths of composites and the other to predict the subsequent notched strengths of composites that are affected by the change in notch sensitivity during fatigue loading. From an efficiency concern, it is desirable to establish a framework for notched fatigue life prediction that is smoothly connected to that for unnotched fatigue life prediction.

The degree of reduction in strength of a composite laminate due to a notch is governed by the intensity of stress concentration in the vicinity of the notch that is affected not only by the strong inherent elastic anisotropy but also by the initiation and growth of multiple non-self-similar cracks in the laminate. The former explains that the notch sensitivity of a composite laminate significantly depends on stacking configuration.2–6 The occurrence of internal inelastic events that are accompanied by the release of local elastic strain energy suggests that the notch sensitivity may be changed during service. In fact, there are many experimental evidences that support diminishing notch sensitivity. For example, it has been observed that the residual strengths of notched composites subjected to fatigue loading often become higher than those in their virgin states not only in tension7–12 but also in compression.13 It has also been observed that the S–N relationship for notched specimens of a composite approaches the S–N relationship for unnotched specimens with increasing number of fatigue cycles.14–16 These experimental observations not only reveal that the fatigue behavior of notched composite laminates is quite different from that of notched metallic materials, but also suggest that the fatigue strength prediction method developed for notched metallic materials is not applicable to notched composite laminates in general. For development of an engineering fatigue life prediction method for notched composite laminates, therefore, we need to consider not only the reduction in strength due to a notch but also the reduction in notch sensitivity during fatigue loading.

Engineering techniques for evaluating the notched strengths of composites, which are indispensable not only for static failure analysis but also for fatigue failure analysis of notched composites, have been investigated by many researchers to date.17 The residual strength of a notched composite observed by experiment is always higher than that predicted using the maximum stress criterion on the basis of the elastic stress concentration at the root of the notch. This is because the notch sensitivity of the composite is reduced by material deterioration and plastic deformation that occur in the vicinity of a notch. For better prediction of the notched strength of a composite, therefore, it is required to model the reduced notch sensitivity of the composite that should physically be related with the stress redistribution at notch tips due to damage and plasticity.18 To this end, Whitney and Nuismer19 proposed two kinds of notch failure criteria that are called the point-stress (PS) and average-stress (AS) criteria. These non-local failure criteria have widely been applied in engineering design analysis of notched composites. For prediction of the notched strength of a composite using either of these notch failure criteria, it is required to identify a characteristic distance ahead of the root of a notch by experiment that determines the notch sensitivity of the composite. This has to be done for each notch size in general, since the characteristic distance is not always constant but it often varies with increasing notch size. To enhance the efficiency of notch failure analysis, the notch size dependence of the characteristic distance of a given composite has been considered in the modified PS failure criterion.20–22

Many attempts have been made to understand the fatigue behavior of notched composite laminates, for example, with respect to the change in notched strength due to cyclic loading7–13 as well as to the growth of damage such as delamination and matrix cracking with cyclic loading and its dependence on stacking configuration.23–25 Considerable attention has also been devoted to modeling of residual strength.26–32 Regarding the development of an analytical technique for predicting the S–N relationships for notched composites, however, only a limited number of articles can be found in literature. Badaliance and Dill33 have developed a master S–N curve approach for the prediction of fatigue life of a notched multidirectional composite laminate. In order to define a master S–N curve that is independent of stress ratio, they assumed a damage correlation parameter based on the concept of strain energy density factor that was proposed by Shi.34 Badaliance and Dill33 demonstrated that a master S–N curve for notched specimens of a graphite/epoxy laminate under compression-dominated fatigue loading can successfully be identified and it can efficiently be used to predict spectrum fatigue life of notched specimens in conjunction with an appropriate damage accumulation rule. While it is an interesting analytical approach for the prediction of fatigue life of notched composite laminates, the master S–N curve approach has not been tested for notched specimens with different notch sizes. A different analytical model formulated by Huh and Hwang35 is also worth reviewing. Huh and Hwang developed an engineering method in which the PS and AS static failure criteria19 are utilized to assess the fatigue failure of a notched carbon fiber-reinforced polymer (CFRP) laminate under the assumption that the stress in the notched section is redistributed36 and the material strength progressively decreases32 with increasing number of cycles during fatigue loading. It was assumed that the characteristic lengths of the PS and AS criteria are material constants and the same values of the characteristic lengths are applicable to both static and fatigue failure analyses. The Huh–Hwang notched fatigue failure criterion takes into account the effect of reduction in notch sensitivity due to cyclic loading on fatigue life by virtue of the assumption of stress redistribution in the notched section during fatigue loading. This method was shown to be valid for prediction of the S–N relationship for a quasi-isotropic CFRP laminate with a circular hole.

While it was intended for the prediction of fatigue life of an impacted CFRP laminate, a method developed by Kang and Kim37 may be applied to the prediction of fatigue life of a notched laminate if the residual strength of an impacted laminate is assumed to be considered as the residual strength of a notched laminate. They assumed that an impacted CFRP laminate may be identified with a fatigued CFRP laminate with the same magnitude of residual strength. Substituting the residual strength of the impacted CFRP laminate for the residual strength after the first of a two-stage fatigue loading in the fatigue life prediction formula developed by Broutman and Sahu,32 we can identify the fatigue life for the second stage fatigue loading in the Broutman–Sahu fatigue life prediction formula with the fatigue life of the impacted CFRP laminate. However, the use of Kang–Kim method as a tool for predicting the fatigue life of a notched laminate has not been attempted and validated by comparison with experimental results. Nyman38 has suggested a fatigue life prediction methodology for notched composite laminates in which the Sims–Brogdon model39 is applied on a laminate level to assess fatigue failure in conjunction with the PS criterion to evaluate notch sensitivity. However, it has not sufficiently been validated by comparison with experimental results.

From a view of engineering implementation, it would be rational and efficient if the fatigue strength of a notched CFRP laminate can accurately be predicted for any fatigue loading on the basis of only a limited number of basic properties. Development of an engineering method that facilitates fatigue analysis of notched composites and explicitly considers the reduction in notch sensitivity during fatigue loading in predicting the S–N relationships for notched composites is of great significance for efficient and reliable fatigue design of CFRP structures. While they suggest practical approaches to this problem, the notched fatigue life prediction methods developed in studies carried out by Huh and Hwang,35 Kang and Kim,37 and Nyman38 have not sufficiently been tested on a variety of notched composite systems with notches of different sizes. Consideration of the change in notch sensitivity during fatigue loading that was observed by experiments is a key to accurate prediction of fatigue life of a notched composite, but it has explicitly been taken into account only by Huh and Hwang35 in their noteworthy attempt. In order to develop an efficient and reliable engineering method for predicting the fatigue lives of notched CFRP laminates, therefore, further experimental and theoretical studies should be accumulated.

This study aims to develop and test a new engineering method for efficiently predicting the S–N relationships for notched CFRP laminates subjected to constant amplitude fatigue loading. In this report, we describe a method for predicting the S–N relationships for notched specimens of CFRP laminates under constant amplitude fatigue loading at a given stress ratio by making use of the S–N relationships for unnotched specimens. Validity of the proposed method is evaluated by comparing with experimental results. For these purposes, constant amplitude fatigue tests are performed on center hole specimens with different diameters as well as unnotched specimens of cross-ply CFRP laminates at room temperature. The S–N relationship for notched specimens of a cross-ply CFRP laminate is compared with that for unnotched specimens to examine the effect of a notch on the fatigue behavior of the composite laminate. Similar fatigue tests on notched specimens and comparison with the results on unnotched specimens are also carried out on different cross-ply CFRP laminates with the same total number of plies but different thicknesses of sub-laminates in order to examine the effect of the ease of local progressive failure in transverse plies on the overall notched fatigue behavior of cross-ply laminates. Then, a new engineering fatigue model is formulated to predict the S–N relationship for a notched laminate under a given constant amplitude fatigue loading for any notch size. It is an integration of a method for predicting the static strength of a notched specimen and a method for predicting the S–N relationship for unnotched specimens. Finally, the S–N curves for notched specimens with different notch sizes are predicted using the proposed methodology for the three kinds of cross-ply CFRP laminates, respectively, and the predictions are compared with the experimental results. Since the test data are limited in number, we attempt to draw only suggestive conclusions from the experimental results on the notched fatigue behavior of the cross-ply laminates. Accordingly, only a potential usefulness of the proposed S–N curve prediction methodology for notched composites is demonstrated in this study.

sec.title: Materials and specimens
sec.p: The prepreg tape P2053F-20 (TORAY) made of the carbon fibers T800H and thermosetting epoxy resin #2500 was used to fabricate three kinds of 12-ply symmetric cross-ply laminates with the different lay-ups of [90/0]3S, [903/03]S, and [03/903]S; they are designated by laminates A, B, and C, respectively. These cross-ply laminates were manufactured by the autoclave forming technique. The curing temperature was 130°C. The thickness of as-received laminates was about 2 mm.

Straight (unnotched) specimens were cut from 400 × 400 mm2 laminate panels to dimensions of the specimen length L = 200 mm, the width W = 20 mm, and the gauge length LG = 100 mm, as shown in Figure 1, following the testing standards JIS K707340 and K7083.41 The aspect ratio of specimens (LG/W) is five. Only on-axis specimens were prepared for this study, and the longitudinal direction (x-axis) of specimens agrees with one of the two fiber directions of the cross-ply laminates. The unnotched tensile strengths of the three kinds of cross-ply laminates are listed in Table 1. The axial elastic modulus Ex and the Poisson’s ratio νxy are as follows: 85.2 GPa and 0.055 for laminate A, 84.9 GPa and 0.042 for laminate B, and 84.1 GPa and 0.045 for laminate C. Figure 1.
Specimen geometry (dimension in mm): (a) unnotched specimen and (b) notched specimen. Table 1.
Unnotched and notched tensile strengths of the three kinds of cross-ply CFRP laminates at room temperature
Type A [90/0]3s Type B [903/03]s Type C [03/903]s
D/W = 0.0 1537.0 1517.0 1459.0
1593.0 1549.0 1507.0
D/W = 0.1 979.3 1204.3 1291.5
1190.1 1190.5 1215.1
D/W = 0.2 744.1 1010.2 983.1
713.4 1057.4 1014.1
D/W = 0.4 533.1 827.6 808.5
509.7 693.7 770.1

Center circular hole specimens (Figure 1(b)) were also prepared. A circular hole was machined at the center of each straight specimen using a drilling machine. The nominal diameter of a hole D was specified as D = 1.0 and 3.0 mm for laminate A: [90/0]3S, and D = 1.0, 3.0, and 6.0 mm for laminates B: [903/03]S and C: [03/903]S. The diameter-to-width ratio was D/W = 0.05 and 0.15 for laminate A, and D/W = 0.05, 0.15, and 0.30 for laminates B and C. The dimension of a hole was machined to a precision of ±3%. The damage by machining in the vicinity of a hole was examined using microscope (VH-8000, Keyence) to a precision of 1 µm, and only the specimens with no appreciable damage were adopted for testing. Rectangular-shaped tabs of 1.0-mm thick aluminum alloy were glued on both ends of specimens with epoxy adhesive (Araldite) in order to protect their gripped portions. The adhesive of tabs was cured for 24 h at room temperature.

Notched tensile strengths of the three kinds of cross-ply laminates used in this study were examined in the previous study42 for different hole diameters D = 2.0, 4.0, and 8.0 mm (D/W = 0.10, 0.20, and 0.40). The diameters of holes of the center hole specimens prepared for this study are different from those of the specimens employed in the previous study, which is intentional. In this study, the initial notched strengths of the center hole specimens used for fatigue testing are predicted using a notched strength model in conjunction with the initial notch sensitivities of the laminates that are identified on the basis of the notched strength data obtained in the previous study.42

sec.title: Fatigue test procedure
sec.p: Constant amplitude fatigue tests were carried out under load control at room temperature. Fatigue load was applied to specimens in a sinusoidal waveform with the constant frequency of 10 Hz and the constant stress ratio of R = 0.1. Fatigue loading condition is based on the testing standard JIS K7083.41 Most specimens were fatigue tested for up to 106 cycles. Fatigue tests were conducted in 100-kN servo hydraulic MTS-810 machine. Each specimen was clamped by the hydraulic wedge grips fitted on the testing machine.

sec.title: Notched strength
sec.p: The notched strengths of the laminates are basic properties, and they are necessary to quantify their notched fatigue behavior. For prediction of the fatigue behavior of a notched laminate which is to be attempted in this study, furthermore, it is a fundamental prerequisite to be able to evaluate its residual strength. The notched strengths and the effect of different stacking configuration of the three kinds of cross-ply laminates tested in this study were already discussed in the previous study.42 We start reviewing the notch sensitivities of the three kinds of laminates42 since they furnish the basis for the subsequent analysis of the notched fatigue behavior.

The notched strengths σN of laminates A, B, and C with a hole of different diameters are presented in Figure 2, together with their unnotched strengths σ0. In this study, the notched strength is defined as the maximum nominal stress in the unnotched section;43 i.e., (1)σN=PmaxA0 where Pmax is the maximum load, and A0 is the unnotched cross-sectional area of specimens. The notched strengths calculated on the gross-section basis are listed in Table 1 for all these laminates, along with their unnotched strengths. Figure 2.
Comparison of the unnotched and notched strengths for cross-ply CFRP laminates A, B, and C.

When comparing the unnotched strengths of cross-ply laminates A, B, and C, it is seen that their magnitudes become smaller in the order A > B > C. However, the difference in unnotched strength between laminates A and C is less than 5%, and thus the effect of the stacking sequence on the ultimate tensile strength of unnotched specimen is negligible in the present case. Each value of unnotched strength is the average of two results. A similar tendency for cross-ply laminate C with a 0° layer on the surface to show a slightly lower unnotched strength than laminate B with a 90° layer on the surface can be found in literature.44,45

On the notched strengths, we can clearly observe the effect of stacking configuration as well as the effect of notch size. The notched strengths of the cross-ply laminates decrease with increasing hole diameter, regardless of stacking configuration, in line with the notch size effect in other materials. The reduction in strength due to a hole for laminate A is more significant than the reductions in strengths for laminates B and C, suggesting that the notch sensitivity of a laminate depends on its staking configuration. More specifically, the ratio of notched to unnotched strength, i.e., notched strength ratio σN/σ0, was 67% in laminate A for D/W = 0.4, but it was 50% in laminate B and 53% in laminate C for the same diameter-to-width ratio. This indicates that the notch sensitivity of laminate A is higher than that those of laminates B and C and the notch sensitivities of laminates B and C are comparable; i.e., A > B ≈ C. Therefore, laminate A is more brittle than the others, suggesting a hole size effect appears more appreciably in laminate A.

Comparison of the ultimate tensile failure modes of laminates A, B, and C shows that delamination occurred more significantly in laminates B and C. Therefore, the experimental results show that specimens failed with larger delamination have higher notched tensile strengths. These observations suggest that damage such as transverse crack and delamination occurred more significantly in laminates B and C, and it reduced stress concentration at notch tips. More significant delamination leads to less notch-sensitive failure. Accordingly, the notched strength ratios for laminates B and C have higher values, and they are distributed at higher locations close to the notch-insensitive (NI) line, as shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Notch sensitivity of cross-ply CFRP laminates A, B, and C.

sec.title: Notch sensitivity
sec.p: The effect of hole size on notched strength can more clearly be observed in the plot of notch strength ratio σN/σ0 against normalized hole diameter D/W. Figure 3 shows the results for laminates A, B, and C. This figure includes the ideally NI and notch-sensitive bounds.

The NI bound is given by the net section stress criterion.46 The net section stress criterion assumes that ultimate failure occurs when the average stress in the notched section (i.e., the net section stress) Snet=σx/(1-α) attains the unnotched strength σ0, in which σx is the nominal stress in the unnotched section. Therefore, the notched strength ratio associated with NI failure is given by (2)σNσ0=1-α where α=D/W.

A notch-sensitive bound, on the other hand, is typically given by the maximum stress criterion. The maximum stress criterion assumes that ultimate failure takes place when the maximum elastic stress Smax=KTσx at the edge of a circular hole reaches the unnotched strength, in which KT is the elastic stress concentration factor for a finite width plate. The notched strength ratio associated with a most notch-sensitive failure is thus given by (3)σNσ0=1KT The formula to calculate the elastic stress concentration factor for a finite width plate has been derived by Tan.47

From Figure 3, it is seen that notch sensitivity data for laminates B and C are distributed near the NI line. Since they are not exactly on the NI line, these laminates are slightly sensitive to a notch. It is also seen that the distribution of the notch sensitivity data for laminate B is close to that for laminate C, suggesting insignificant difference in notch sensitivity between these laminates. The notch strength ratio for laminate A, on the other hand, is smaller than the values for the other kinds of laminates, and thus the notch sensitivity data for laminate A are distributed in the middle of the bounds and they are closer to the notch sensitive line than the data for laminates B and C. These results show that the notch sensitivity of laminate A is clearly higher than the notch sensitivity of laminates B and C.

sec.title: S–N relationship for unnotched specimens
sec.p:
The S–N relationships for unnotched specimens of the three kinds of cross-ply laminates A, B, and C are shown in Figure 4, as plots of maximum fatigue stress (σmax) against the number of reversals (2Nf). The arrows indicate the data run-out at 106 cycles. Dashed lines indicate the S–N curves fitted to the fatigue data for laminates B and C, respectively. Figure 4.
S–N relationships for unnotched cross-ply CFRP laminates A, B, and C.

From Figure 4, it is seen that the S–N relationships for laminates A and B almost agree with each other. By contrast, the fatigue strength of laminate C in the long life range is lower than that for laminate A or laminate B. The following reasons48 may be suggested for the lower fatigue strength of laminate C: (1) the 90° plies are thicker in laminate C, and thus larger transverse cracks that extend through all the 90° plies in laminate C are developed during fatigue loading; (2) the final crack density in laminate C is larger than that in laminates A and B; (3) according to (2), the reduction in stiffness is larger in laminate C.

sec.title: S–N relationship for notched specimens
sec.p: The effect of notch on the S–N relationships for the three kinds of cross-ply laminates is similar. Here, we will observe only the results for laminate B as the representative, but the results for the other laminates are presented below when discussing the predictive accuracy of a fatigue life prediction model for notched laminates that is developed later in this study.

Figure 5 shows the S–N relationships for notched specimens of laminate B. This figure includes fatigue data for different diameters of holes D/W = 0.05, 0.15, and 0.30, along with a dashed line fitted to the fatigue data for unnotched specimens D/W = 0. The arrows in Figure 5 indicate data run-out at 106 cycles. The maximum fatigue stress for notched specimens is defined as the maximum fatigue load Fmax divided by the unnotched cross-sectional area, i.e., (4)σmax=FmaxA0 The initial notched static strength levels for different notch sizes, which are predictions using a notched strength model described later, are also indicated on the vertical axis of Figure 5. Figure 5.
S–N relationships for notched specimens of cross-ply CFRP laminate B:[903/03]S.

From Figure 5, it is seen that in the range of short life, the S–N relationship is shifted downward with increasing diameter of a hole, according to the reduction in residual strength. By contrast, the S–N relationships for notched specimens, especially in the case D/W = 0.05 and 0.15, tends to approach the S–N relationship for unnotched specimens in the range of long life, suggesting that notch sensitivity disappears during fatigue loading. While it is likely, this tendency cannot completely be justified in this study for notched specimens with the largest hole D/W = 0.3 since only a few data are available and a possible approach to the S–N relationship for unnotched specimens occurs in the range of more than 107 cycles. A similar tendency for the S–N relationship for notched specimens of a polymer matrix composite to approach the S–N relationship for unnotched specimens in the range of long life can be found in the experimental results reported so far.14–16

sec.title: Diminishing notch sensitivity during fatigue loading
sec.p:
Bathias49 has observed that the normalized S–N relationships for unnotched and notched specimens which are plotted using the unnotched and notched fatigue strength ratios σmax/σ0 and σmax/σN, respectively, agree with each over the range of fatigue life. It is examined whether this is applicable to the fatigue data obtained in this study. Figure 6 shows the fatigue data for laminate B that are plotted using unnotched and notched strength ratios for all notch sizes. Because of a limited number of samples, static tension tests were not performed on notched specimens with the hole diameters assumed for fatigue testing. Therefore, the notched strengths of the specimens used for fatigue testing were evaluated using a notch failure criterion described later. From Figure 6, it is seen that the normalized S–N relationships for notched specimens agree well with each other, regardless of notch size. Accordingly, the shapes of the S–N relationships for notched specimens with different hole diameters are similar, and they collapse into a single S–N relationship when the maximum fatigue stresses are scaled. It is thus suggested that the notch size dependence of the S–N relationship for laminate B can be removed using notched strength ratio. Comparing the normalized S–N relationship for notched specimens with that for unnotched specimens in Figure 6, we can see that the normalized fatigue data on notched specimens (σmax/σN) tend to be distributed slightly above the normalized fatigue data on unnotched specimens (σmax/σ0). This indicates that the relative fatigue strength of notched specimens is slightly larger than that of unnotched specimens. The same feature can be found in the notched fatigue behavior observed in the previous study.50 While more data may be required to quantify it, the difference observed in Figure 6 suggests that the S–N relationships for unnotched and notched specimens cannot always be dealt with in a unified manner by normalization with respect to their initial strengths. Figure 6.
Normalized S–N relationships for notched specimens of cross-ply CFRP laminate B:[903/03]S.

On the other hand, the reduction in notch sensitivity means that notched specimens are apt to fail in a mode that is controlled by the net section stress. The maximum fatigue stress in the notched section, Snet(max), can be calculated as (5)Snet(max)=11-ασmax

Note that σmax is the maximum fatigue stress in the unnotched section. Here, we replot the fatigue data in Figure 5 using the net section maximum fatigue stress. Figure 7 shows the results. In Figure 7, we can confirm that the S–N relationships for notched specimens that are based on the net section maximum fatigue stress are in good agreement with the S–N relationship for unnotched specimens, regardless of notch size. A good agreement between the S–N relationships for unnotched and notched specimens in Figure 7 with respect to the net section maximum fatigue stress suggests that the stress concentration, i.e., notch sensitivity, of notched specimens disappears during fatigue loading. Figure 7.
Net section stress-based S–N relationships for notched specimens of cross-ply laminate B:[903/03]S.

These observations in Figures 6 and 7, which are common to what are observed for the other kinds of cross-ply laminates, suggest that the fatigue lives of notched specimens are determined by their initial notched strengths in the range of short life, but in the range of long life they are apt to be controlled by the average stress in the notched section. In accurately describing the notched fatigue strengths of the cross-ply CFRP laminates, therefore, we need to take into account that the residual strengths of notched cross-ply laminates change from the initial notched strength σN to the NI strength σNI=(1-α)σ0.

sec.title: Notched static strength prediction method
sec.p: For the prediction of the S–N relationship for a notched composite, it is a prerequisite to evaluate its notched static strength. It is convenient if a notched static strength model to be used for this purpose is applicable to notched specimens of any notch sizes. In the context of this study, it is also required that both the notch sensitive and NI failure can explicitly and easily be taken into account in evaluation of the notched strength of a given laminate. The following notched static strength model comes up to these requirements, and thus it is adopted for the purpose of predicting the notched strengths of the cross-ply laminates tested in this study.

sec.title: Notch-insensitive failure criterion
sec.p: NI failure in a given composite can be predicted using the net section stress criterion.46 The net section stress criterion can be expressed as (6)fNI≡(Snetσ0)2=(11-ασxσ0)2=1 where σx is a remote uniform stress in the unnotched section of a notched composite laminate, and σ0 is the unnotched strength of the composite. This failure criterion yields the NI strength ratio: (7)σNIσ0=1-α which gives the NI bound in Figure 3. Note that σNI indicates the NI strength calculated on the gross section basis.

sec.title: Crack mechanics-based failure criterion
sec.p: Most brittle failure in a given material can be predicted using the Griffith fracture mechanics criterion.46 Identifying a circular hole of diameter D with a fictitious crack of length 2a (=D), we can describe the Griffith fracture mechanics criterion as follows: (8)KI=KIC where KI is the stress intensity factor for mode I loading, and KIC is a critical value at failure; it is called the fracture toughness for mode I loading. The mode I stress intensity factor is defined as (9)KI=σxπa for an idealized infinite material with a crack of length 2a under far-field uniform stress σx.46

The stress intensity factor for mode I crack tip deformation that was described above is based on linear elastic fracture mechanics (LEFM), and it defines the intensity of the near crack-tip stress field with the singularity of the order of r-0.5 (r is the distance from a crack tip). In a material that exhibits nonlinear response or at an interface between different materials, the order of crack tip stress singularity is different from that based on LEFM and it is expressed as r-λ in general.51,52

For the sake of simplicity, let us consider a nonlinear elastic material that is characterized by a constitutive relation of the following form: (10)σσref=(ɛɛref)λ1-λ By means of the Neuber rule53 for stress and strain concentration, an analytical expression of approximate stress distribution in the vicinity of a notch root can be derived.54 The analytical formula further allows us to derive another analytical formula for approximate stress distribution at a tip of a crack of length 2a in the nonlinear elastic material under remote loading σx, suggesting a generalized stress intensity factor of the following form: (11)K~I=σxπa2λ with the condition of failure (12)K~I=K~IC where K~IC is a critical value of the generalized stress intensity factor defined by Equation (11). The failure criterion given by Equation (12) is equivalent to the Mar–Lin55 failure criterion. Assuming λ = 0.5, the generalized failure criterion, Equation (12), can be reduced to the form, Equation (8), based on LEFM.

Taking into account a general stress singularity at a crack tip and adopting the failure condition given by Equation (12), instead of Equation (8), we assume that most brittle failure in a composite material can be expressed as (13)fNS≡(K~IK~IC)2=(F~I(α)πα2λκ~σxσ0)2=1 where the coefficient κ~ in Equation (13) designates the normalized fracture toughness defined as56 (14)κ~=K~ICσ0b2λ where b=W/2. In the case of λ = 0.5, the non-dimensional coefficient κ~ agrees with the stress brittleness number.57 The coefficient F~I(α) is a finite width correction factor.

sec.title: Transitional brittle–ductile failure criterion
sec.p: The experimental results for notched specimens of the three kinds of cross-ply laminates used in this study show not only that they exhibit moderate static notch sensitivities that lie between the notch sensitive and NI bounds, regardless of stacking configuration, but also that the magnitude of notch sensitivity depends on stacking configuration. These observations suggest the need for a notched static failure criterion for composite laminates that can account for any static failure in the brittle-to-ductile transition region in order to accurately predict their notched strengths.

Combining the net section stress criterion and the crack mechanics-based criterion, we can formulate a notched failure criterion that is applicable to composites with any notch sensitivities in the range bounded by the NI limit and the notch-sensitive limit. In this study, we assume the combined failure criterion of the following form: (15)fN=fNI+fNS=(Snetσ0)2+(K~IK~IC)2=1

Substituting the limit failure criteria given by Equations (6) and (13) and solving the resulting algebraic equation with respect to an applied remote stress, we can derive the following formula to calculate a notched strength ratio: (16)σNσ0=11(1-α)2+F~I2(πα)2λκ~2

Note that σN represents a notched strength on the gross-section basis. The parameter κ~ determines the magnitude of notch sensitivity, and λ controls the shape of the notch sensitivity curve (σN/σ0 vs. α) for a given material. When using this formula, we assume that κ~ and λ are treated as parameters that are identified by fitting Equation (16) to the notch sensitivity curve for a given material. The notched strength prediction model expressed by Equation (16) considers the effect of variable singularity at a crack tip and it can be used over the whole range of α, i.e., 0≤α≤1, and thus it can deal with the unnotched strength as well as the notched strength of a given material. Assuming λ = 0.5, we can reduce the notched strength prediction formula given by Equation (16) to a form similar to that proposed by Suo et al.58

sec.title: Comparison with experimental results
sec.p: To predict the notched strengths of the three kinds of cross-ply laminates using the formula given by Equation (16), we need to identify their unnotched strengths σ0, notch sensitivity scale parameters κ~, and notch sensitivity shape parameters λ. The unnotched strengths σ0 of the cross-ply laminates are evaluated by static tests. The notched strength prediction model proposed in this study is insensitive to the value of notch sensitivity shape parameter λ only at the normalized notch size of α=1/π. This means that the notch sensitivity scale parameter κ~ can be evaluated using the following formula: (17)κ~=F~I(σNσ0|α=1/π)-2-(11-1/π)2

Note that the determination of κ~ by means of Equation (17) is not affected by the order of stress singularity λ. The remaining parameter λ is identified by fitting Equation (16) to the plots of notched strength ratio (σN/σ0) against diameter-to-width ratio (α = D/W) for a given material. In this study, it was assumed that the finite width correction factor F~I is given by the following expression59 for an isotropic finite width plate: (18)FI=(1-0.025α2+0.06α4)secπα2

The unnotched strengths σ0 of the cross-ply laminates that were evaluated by tension tests are listed in Table 1. Since the notched strength at α=1/π was not measured, and thus (σN/σ0)|α=1/π was evaluated by interpolation of notched strength data available. The values of κ~ were then calculated using Equation (17) in conjunction with the unnotched strengths σ0 obtained by experiment, the notched strength ratios (σN/σ0)|α=1/π evaluated by interpolation and Equation (18). They were obtained as follows: 0.50 for laminate A, 1.10 for laminate B, and 1.25 for laminate C. By fitting Equation (16) to the notch sensitivity curve assuming these values of κ~ and σ0, the notch sensitivity shape parameter was evaluated as λ = 0.48. The agreements between the experimental notch sensitivity curves and the fitted curves using these values were not sufficient for laminates B and C. In order to obtain better fitting of Equation (16) to the experimental notch sensitivity curves for the three kinds of laminates, therefore, we applied a trial and error method. The values of κ~ and λ at which we finally arrived are listed in Table 2. Table 2.
Notch sensitivity parameters for the three kinds of cross-ply CFRP laminates at room temperature
Type A [90/0]3s Type B [903/03]s Type C [03/903]s
κ~ 0.470 0.996 1.276
λ 0.5 0.5 0.5

The solid lines in Figure 8 indicate the notch sensitivity curves we finally obtained by fitting Equation (16) to the experimental data for the three kinds of laminates, respectively. Symbols in Figure 8 indicate the notched strength ratios for α = D/W = a/b = 0.1, 0.2, and 0.4, respectively. It is seen that accurate description of notch sensitivity curve has been achieved for the different laminates, respectively. Incidentally, the notch sensitivity scale parameter is the normalized fracture toughness of a material considered. A smaller value of notch sensitivity scale parameter suggests that the material is more sensitive to a notch and thus it fails in a more brittle manner. The order of the values of notch sensitivity scale parameter that are listed in Table 2 suggests that laminate A is more sensitive to a notch than laminates B and C. Figure 8.
Prediction of notch size effect in different cross-ply laminates A, B, and C.

sec.title: Notched fatigue life prediction method
sec.p: By combining the above-mentioned notched static strength model with the fatigue damage mechanics model60 for describing the S–N relationships for unnotched composites, a new analytical fatigue life prediction method for notched composites is developed.

sec.title: Unnotched fatigue strength model
sec.p: In the previous study,60 it was assumed that the intensity of fatigue damage in orthotropic composites can be described using a single scalar variable ω, and its evolution equation can be prescribed by the following equation: (19)dωdN=Aψn(11-ω)káψ-ψLñmá1-ψñℓ where ψ is the fatigue strength ratio defined as (20)ψ=σmaxσ0 The coefficients A, k, n, ℓ, m, and ψL are fatigue constants. The angular brackets áñ denote the singular function defined as áxñ=max{0,x}.

Integration of Equation (19) with the assumption that fatigue failure occurs at ω=1 yields the following form of fatigue life prediction equation for unnotched fatigue behavior: (21)Nf=1(1+k)Aψná1-ψñℓáψ-ψLñm The material constants involved by Equation (21) can be determined by fitting it to the S–N relationship for unnotched specimens of a given material.

The fatigue life prediction equation for unnotched composites that is given by Equation (21) includes three basic non-dimensional functions: (22)Φ0S=á1-ψñℓ (23)Φ0L=áψ-ψLñm (24)Φ0F=ψn These basic functions play the following important roles. The function Φ0S allows to describe the fatigue behavior in which fatigue life rapidly shortens as maximum fatigue stress approaches static strength; i.e., the description of static strength dependence of fatigue life. The function Φ0L furnishes the fatigue life prediction equation with a capability to predict infinite life for maximum fatigue stress below a fatigue limit. The use of the function Φ0F suggests that the S–N relationship for a middle level of maximum fatigue stress between the static strength and a fatigue limit is approximately described by means of a power-law function of the Basquin61 type.

sec.title: Notched fatigue strength model with consideration of vanishing notch sensitivity
sec.p: The fatigue life prediction equation for unnotched composites is modified into a form that can be used for predicting the S–N relationships for notched composites under a given constant amplitude fatigue loading.

It was observed that the S–N relationships for notched specimens of laminates A, B, and C rapidly approach the S–N relationships for unnotched specimens of those laminates, regardless of stacking configuration, in line with the observations in literature.14–16 Such a characteristic fatigue behavior of notched composites is modeled by replacing the basic functions involved by the fatigue life prediction equation for unnotched composites, Equation (21), with their modified versions that take into account vanishing notch sensitivity during fatigue loading.
First, we replace the function Φ0S for unnotched composites with that for notched composites defined as (25)ΦNS=á1-ψNñℓ where ψN is the notched fatigue strength ratio calculated as (26)ψN=σmaxσN

Next, it is assumed that the notch sensitivity of notched specimens vanishes in the range of long life and the S–N relationship for notched specimens approach that for unnotched specimens therein. Accordingly, the basic functions that control the fatigue behavior in the range from a middle to low stress level are replaced with the following functions: (27)ΦNL=áψNI-ψNI(L)ñm (28)ΦNF=ψNIn where ψNI is the NI fatigue strength ratio defined as (29)ψNI=σmaxσNI Since the NI strength was defined as σNI=(1-α)σ0, the NI fatigue strength ratio associated with a fatigue limit, in case it exists, can be expressed as ψNI(L)=ψL/(1-α).

Replacement of the three basic functions for unnotched composites with their modified versions yields the following fatigue life prediction equation for notched composites: (30)Nf(N)=1(1+k)AψNIná1-ψNñℓáψNI-ψNI(L)ñm The material constants involved by Equation (30) for notched composites are assumed to be identical with those involved by Equation (21) for unnotched composites. Thus, they are determined by fitting Equation (21) to the S–N relationship for unnotched specimens.

Note that ψNI≠ψ since ψNI=σmax/σNI=ψ/(1-α). Therefore, the S–N relationship predicted using Equation (30) does not coincide with the S–N relationship for unnotched configuration even in a long life range. Instead, it approaches the following S–N relationship associated with the purely NI (net section stress-based) fatigue failure: (31)Nf(NI)=1(1+k)AψNIná1-ψNIñℓáψNI-ψNI(L)ñm It is obvious that we can reduce the fatigue life prediction equation, Equation (30), for notched composites to the fatigue life prediction equation, Equation (21), for unnotched composites by assuming as α=0.

Once the static strength and notch sensitivity parameters of a given composite and the S–N relationship for unnotched specimens of the composite are identified, the S–N relationship for notched specimens of the composite can be predicted for any notch size using the formula given by Equation (30). It is emphasized that two capabilities to predict the notched static and fatigue strengths of a given composite are furnished in a unified manner with the vanishing notch sensitivity approach proposed in this study.

sec.title: Comparison with experimental results
sec.p:
The S–N relationships for notched specimens of the three kinds of cross-ply laminates were predicted using the proposed vanishing notch sensitivity method for fatigue life prediction. The predicted results for the three kinds of cross-ply laminates are shown in Figures 9–11, respectively, with experimental results. The dashed lines in these figures indicate the S–N relationships for unnotched specimens. The material constants that were identified by fitting Equation (21) to the S–N relationships for unnotched specimens of the cross-ply laminates are listed in Table 3. A fatigue limit was not clearly seen in the S–N relationship for unnotched specimens, regardless of stacking configuration of the cross-ply laminates, and thus it was assumed that m=0. Figure 9.
Prediction of S–N relationships for notched specimens of cross-ply CFRP laminate A:[90/0]3S. Figure 10.
Prediction of S–N relationships for notched specimens of cross-ply CFRP laminate B:[903/03]S. Figure 11.
Prediction of S–N relationships for notched specimens of cross-ply CFRP laminate C:[03/903]S. Table 3.
Material constants involved by the fatigue life equation for the three kinds of unnotched cross-ply CFRP laminates at room temperature
(1 + k)A N ℓ m
Type A [90/0]3s 0.02 18 1 0
Type B [903/03]s 0.9 28 0.2 0
Type C [03/903]s 0.003 9 1 0

Figures 9–11 show that the S–N relationship for notched specimens tends to approach the S–N relationship for unnotched specimens, suggesting that wear-in occurred in these laminates. The notched fatigue data for D/W = 0.05 in Figures 9 and 11 almost coincide with the unnotched fatigue data. The notched fatigue data should be distributed at slightly shorter lives compared with the unnotched fatigue data, as in Figure 10. Therefore, more fatigue data are necessary to distinguish between the notched fatigue behavior for D/W = 0.05 and the unnotched fatigue behavior.

While they show only limited number of fatigue data, Figures 9–11 suggest overall agreements between the predicted and experimental S–N relationships for notched specimens for the three kinds of cross-ply laminates with different stacking configurations, respectively. It is emphasized that the notched fatigue data were not used to determine the material constants involved by the fatigue life prediction equation. As mentioned earlier, the hole diameters of the specimens used for fatigue tests are different from those of the specimens used for notched tension tests to identify notch sensitivity, and thus the predicted notched strengths were used when calculating the fatigue lives of the notched specimens. Therefore, these comparisons between the prediction and experimental results in Figures 9–11 verify the validity of the proposed fatigue life prediction method for notched composite laminates with different notch sensitivities. Thus, it may be concluded that the vanishing notch sensitivity approach developed in this study is a promising step in predicting the fatigue lives of the notched cross-ply laminates with different staking configurations.

sec.title: Consideration of fading notch sensitivity
sec.p: Notch sensitivity was assumed to vanish in deriving the fatigue life prediction equation (Equation (30)). This formula can be extended to deal with fading notch sensitivity during fatigue loading. In that case, the notch sensitivity parameters enter the formula as functions of the number of cycles. Accordingly, the evolution equation of damage that is yielded by substitution of the modified functions Equations (25), (27), and (28) in Equation (19) turns nonlinear with respect to the number of cycles. This requires us to integrate the differential equation numerically for evaluating the fatigue life of a given notched specimen. The additional capability to consider fading notch sensitivity during fatigue loading expands the range of application of the proposed methodology. As far as the cross-ply laminates tested in this study are concerned, however, consideration of fading notch sensitivity during fatigue loading leads to predictions of slightly shorter fatigue lives for all conditions, and thus it results in no improvement in the agreement between the predicted and observed fatigue lives of the notched specimens.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The effect of notch on the S–N relationships for three kinds of symmetric cross-ply carbon/epoxy laminates with different stacking configurations (A:[90/0]3S, B:[903/03]S and C:[03/903]S) was examined. The notch size effect in fatigue of those laminates was quantified by comparing the results for different notch sizes. A new engineering model to predict the S–N curves for composite laminates was then developed on the basis of the concept of vanishing notch sensitivity. Finally, the validity of the proposed notched fatigue life prediction method was evaluated by comparing with experimental results. The results obtained can be summarized as follows:
The S–N relationships for center hole specimens of the cross-ply CFRP laminates tend to approach the S–N relationships for unnotched specimens in the range of long fatigue life, regardless of notch size and stacking configuration.
The normalized S–N relationships for notched specimens that were plotted using the notched fatigue strength ratio σmax/σN agree well with each other, regardless of notch size and stacking configuration. The agreement suggests that the difference between the S–N relationships for notched specimens is strongly affected by the difference between their residual strengths.
The normalized fatigue data for notched specimens (σmax/σN) tend to be distributed slightly above the normalized fatigue data for unnotched specimens (σmax/σ0). This apparently indicates that the relative fatigue strength of notched specimens is slightly larger than that of unnotched specimens. This feature along with the previous one suggests that the S–N relationships for unnotched and notched specimens cannot always be dealt with in a unified manner by normalization with respect to their initial (unnotched and notched) strengths.
The S–N relationships for notched specimens using the net section maximum fatigue stress are in good agreement with the S–N relationship for unnotched specimens, regardless of notch size and stacking configuration. This observation suggests that the notch sensitivity of the cross-ply laminates disappears during fatigue loading due to damage developing in the vicinity of notch tips.
A vanishing notch sensitivity approach to prediction of fatigue life of notched composites was developed by means of the notched static strength model that is applicable to composites with a notch of any size and the fatigue damage mechanics model that allows evaluating the fatigue life of unnotched composites. The proposed notched fatigue model has features that it is applicable to composites with any notch sensitivity as well as with a notch of any size.
The proposed model can explain the characteristic features of the notched fatigue behaviors of the cross-ply laminates. It suggests that the model has the potential of giving reasonable predictions regardless of notch size and stacking configuration, but it should be validated in quantitative terms on the basis of more experimental data.
The framework of the notched fatigue model developed in this study is general enough to accommodate itself to fading notch sensitivity during fatigue loading, although it was only suggested in this study.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ack.p: This study was supported in part by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology of Japan under a Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research (no. 20360050).

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
